journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Effect of inter-string friction on tennis ball rebound

article-meta.aff: 1Centre for Sports Engineering Research, Sheffield Hallam University, Sheffield, UK
2Department of Engineering and Maths, Sheffield Hallam University, Sheffield, UK

author-notes.corresp: Steve Haake, Centre for Sports Engineering Research, Sheffield Hallam University, Collegiate Hall, Collegiate Crescent, Sheffield S10 2BP, UK. Email: s.j.haake@shu.ac.uk

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Tribology of Sport

abstract.p: Tennis players report anecdotally that the choice of string material affects the amount of spin applied to the ball by the racket. Previous research on the effect of the coefficient of friction of tennis strings has concluded that ball rebound is mostly, but not always, independent of the string friction. To understand this better, tennis balls were projected at a fixed racket at 25 m·s−1 with backspin varying from 0 to 400 rad·s−1 at an angle of 40° and 60° to the normal with strings made from either nylon or polyester. Each string type was modified by lubricating it to give low friction or sanding it to give high friction. It was shown that the inter-string friction μs had different consequences depending upon whether the strings slid across each other during contact. The ball tended to roll at high μs, unless the inbound backspin was high enough to induce slipping. A decrease in μs allowed slipping of the strings over each other which reduced the horizontal impulse applied to the ball. At very low μs the ball was induced to overspin at steep impacts or slip at shallow angles. It was concluded that the dominant effect of a change in inter-string friction was in the string movement rather than the coefficient of friction between the ball and strings, and that the effect was dependent upon impact angle and spin.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There are many varieties of tennis strings currently available on the market, synthetic strings made from nylon and polyester make up the majority. Players agree that some strings tend to allow them to produce more spin than others but the best gauge, tension or type is not agreed upon. Some authors have shown that the speed, angle and spin of the rebounding ball is dependent upon the stiffness and coefficient of friction of the strings, μs.1–7 The term μs is often not well defined in the literature with it sometimes referring to the friction between the ball and the strings and sometimes the inter-string friction; in this case μs will refer to the inter-string friction.

The oblique impact of a tennis ball with a surface is relatively complex and the specific mechanics are dependent on the initial conditions. Goodwill et al.1 used an apparatus specially designed for the International Tennis Federation to compare string stiffness with spin generation. They concluded that the stiffer polyester strings generated around 20% more spin at an inbound angle of 40° to the racket normal compared to nylon strings, and about 20% less at 60° to the racket normal.

Early research by Brody8 showed that when impacting a rigid surface a ball may slip or roll with more slipping occurring at shallower impact angles. Rolling can be considered to be the state of dynamic equilibrium. More recent studies have shown that a ball can spin faster than associated with rolling during an impact with a rigid surface9–13 or a tennis racket string bed.1,10,14,15 The ball is said to be ‘over-spinning’ when it spins faster than rolling. Allen et al.,10,14 Cross11 and Goodwill et al.13 showed that during over-spinning the direction of the frictional force between the ball and surface can reverse direction. The characteristics of overspin are tangential rebound speeds that are low (often with large rebound angles with respect to the normal) and with large rebound topspins.9,11 During contact it is possible for the ball to oscillate between slip with backspin or overslip with topspin; these periods of slip and overslip may damp out if contact is long enough so that the final equilibrium state is rolling. More generally, however, the ball rebounds either slipping or overslipping.

Relatively few studies have measured string friction or investigated the effect on impact mechanics. The dynamic coefficient of friction between the ball and strings has been shown to be around 0.3 to 0.416 while the inter-string dynamic coefficient of friction has been shown to be considerably lower at around 0.04 to 0.10.17 Cross11 produced an analytical model to account for the effects of ball-to-string friction coefficients which did not account for over-spin. Allen et al.10,14 went further with a finite element model of a tennis ball impact with a racket. They showed that at inbound angles less than 23° (relative to the string bed normal) the ball was likely to roll and the rebound spin was essentially independent of the ball-to-string coefficient of friction. Increasing the inbound angle to 40° resulted in higher rebound spin when the coefficient of friction was 0.2 in comparison to 0.6.10 These findings further highlight the complexity of the impact and the mechanisms dependency on the initial conditions. The friction between the balls and the strings is also likely to affect the mechanics of the impact. Kawazoe and Okimoto3 found that by lubricating the strings and reducing string-to-string friction in player tests, spin generation was increased by up to 30% whilst Lindsey6 found a 14–58% increase in a laboratory experiment.

Thus, while the ball-string coefficient of friction has been measured during impact testing, the inter-string coefficient of friction has not been used as the primary variable in testing. The purpose of this paper, therefore, is to vary the coefficient of friction of tennis strings, to clarify its effect on ball rebound and suggest a mechanism for impact that is able to account for the wide range of effects seen in the literature. Testing will be undertaken at a range of initial conditions in an attempt to gain a holistic understanding of the mechanics involved.

sec.title: Ball impacts
sec.p:
Two types of string were selected for analysis: a nylon string and a polyester string. Each string was tested under three conditions:
Unmodified strings.
Strings coated with WD-40 lubricant (low friction).
Strings sanded with medium-grade emery paper (high friction).

A bespoke apparatus was used to measure the motion of the ball before and after impact, as detailed in Goodwill and Haake.1 A modified ball projection device (BOLA, UK) was used to project a spinning ball directly at the centre of a racket with it fully constrained in a rigid steel frame that could be rotated to alter the impact angle (Figure 1). Testing was carried out using an ITF Development racket with a strung area of 632 cm2 (98 in2) and with a string tension of 270 N. Following stringing, each racket was left for at least 24 hours prior to testing in ambient conditions of 20 ± 2°C and 60 ± 5% relative humidity to allow for the string bed stiffness to stabilize. Figure 1.
Schematic of the impact apparatus and definitions for spin before and after impact, and forces during impact.

The nominal inbound ball speed vi was 25 m·s−1 with backspin ωi varying from 0 to 400 rad·s−1 at an angle θi of 40° and 60° to the normal. The use of backspin is consistent with the ball in the tennis court frame in which a ball rebounds from the court surface and impacts with a moving tennis racket. Backspin was defined as positive for the inbound ball while topspin was defined as positive for the rebounding ball (Figure 1). Strings were reset to the original position before each impact.

The ball was tracked before and after impact using a high speed video camera (Phantom v4, Vision Research) operating at 1000 Hz using bespoke software. The uncertainty in the measured velocity and spin was less than 2%.1 The vertical and horizontal impulse of the impacts was calculated using (1) and (2) where R(t) and F(t) are vertical and horizontal contact forces at time t, respectively (Figure 1), T is the contact time and m is the mass of the ball. The horizontal impulse is defined to be positive when acting in the opposite direction to the motion of the ball (Figure 1).

The time averaged coefficient of friction between the ball and strings can be found using ∫0 TF(t)dt=-μt∫o TR(t)dt where μt is defined as the dynamic friction or ‘traction’ coefficient of the impact (to distinguish it from the inter-string coefficient of friction μs). The time averaged traction coefficient can thus be approximated using (3)

If the ball slides throughout the impact, then the magnitude of μt will represent the standard definition of coefficient of friction between a ball and strings. If the ball rolls for a substantial portion of the impact, then μt will be lower than the standard definition since Δvx reduces to zero at some point during the impact.

The rebound spin ratio Sr was used during analysis and was calculated using (4) where ωr is the rebound spin (defined as positive for clockwise spin in Figure 1), r is the radius of the ball (33 mm) and vrx is the relative tangential velocity between the surface and rebounding ball. Sr < 1 indicates slipping, Sr > 1 indicates overspinning while Sr = 1 indicates rolling. Both ωr and vrx may change sign and Sr represents the relative motion between the outside of the ball and the string bed at the end of impact. Spin ratio has been shown to be a suitable measure for impacts on a rigid surface9 or the string bed of a head-clamped racket.1,15 However, large tangential string movements could lead to uncertainty in measured values of vrx and hence Sr.

sec.title: String characteristics
sec.p:
There is no industry standard for measuring string friction, so a bespoke test rig was developed for this research (Figure 2). A pendulum, consisting of a vertical tennis string with a 1 kg mass attached to its end, was constructed to give a measure of the inter-string friction μs. A second string was held horizontally across rollers with two 12.5 kg masses used to apply a load of 122 N. The pendulum string was fixed above the horizontal one but offset to one side such that it touched the middle of the horizontal string at 30° to the vertical in order to apply a load between the strings. The pendulum string was allowed to swing from side to side along the horizontal string and was released at an initial angle to the vertical of 32°. A high-speed video camera (Phantom v4.3, Vision Research) filming at 100 frames per second was used to determine the time period between the release of the main string and the time τ at which it came to rest which was then taken as a measure of friction. Thus a small τ indicated a large μs and vica versa and in the discussion of results the term μs will be used preferably when discussing the effects of inter-string friction rather than the experimental measure τ. Figure 2.
Pendulum rig used to give a measure of inter-string friction.

The two string types were also tested using an Instron v5543 machine to allow stiffness k to be calculated. The stiffness in Newton per·millimeter was determined by loading the string along its axis to 280 N followed by further loading at 0.83 mm·s−1 to 380 N and measuring the deflection, as detailed in Cross.18 The gauge length was 200 mm. The results for inter-string friction and string stiffness are displayed in Table 1. Table 1.
Pendulum test to estimate inter-string friction, and string stiffness.
Friction test: time for pendulum to come to rest τ (s) Stiffness k (N mm−1)
Polyester low 17.9 93
Polyester 14.6 93
Nylon low 12.7 37
Nylon 10.7 37
Polyester high 6.8 93
Nylon high 4.6 37

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Linear regressions were performed on vr, θr and ωr and the derived values of Ix, Iy and μt with respect to ωi for the two values of θi. Additionally, stepwise linear multiple regressions were used to determine the effect of μt, k, vi, θi and ωi on the rebound parameters. This form of regression enters the input parameters in order of significance and gives standardized β coefficients to indicate their weighting in the final regression equation. Values of Radj 2 and the standard error of the estimate SEE were reported for each dependent variable.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The results are displayed in two sections:
Overview of impact mechanics for unmodified nylon strings.
Effect of inter-string friction.

sec.title: Impact mechanics
sec.p:
Figure 3(a) shows a sample set of velocity vectors before and after impact for the unmodified nylon strings. The mean vector is shown for the inbound ball with the standard deviations in vertical and horizontal speed indicated by the error bars. Individual impacts are shown for the rebound vectors. The dashed arrow on the rebound vectors indicates the effect of varying inbound backspin from 0 to 400 rad·s−1. The data shows that steeper impacts rebound faster and closer to the normal. An increase in inbound backspin reduces the speed, angle and topspin of the rebounding ball (Figure (b) to (d)). This is confirmed by Table 2 which shows that, in general, the inbound angle and spin are the dominant variables controlling rebound. Figure 3.
Impacts of pressurized tennis balls on a rigidly clamped tennis racket with nylon strings at 25 m·s−1 with backspin varying from 0 to 400 rad·s−1: (a) inbound and outbound velocity vectors with respect to the racket frame; (b) rebound speed vr; (c) rebound angle θr with respect to the normal; (d) rebound spin ωr. Figure 4(a) and (b) show the vertical and horizontal impulses calculated using equations (1) and (2). Iy is relatively constant with ωi (with a very weak effect in Table 2) and is about 50% larger at 40° than at 60°. Ix is higher at 60° than at 40° and increases with inbound backspin (with a strong effect in Table 2). Figure 4(c) shows the coefficient of restitution (COR); it can be seen that, as with Iy, it remains relatively constant with inbound backspin. Figure 4.
Impacts of pressurized tennis balls on a rigidly clamped tennis racket with nylon strings at 25 m·s−1 with spin varying from 0 to 400 rad·s−1: (a) vertical impulse Iy; (b) horizontal impulse Ix; (c) coefficient of restitution (y) and (d) traction μt.

The variation in Ix and Iy suggests that they are not necessarily controlled by the same physical parameters. Figure 4(d) shows the effect of inbound spin and angle on the traction coefficient calculated using equation (3). It can be seen that μt increases with impact angle and backspin and at 60° is double the value at 40°. μt is not, therefore, a constant parameter but is affected strongly by inbound backspin and angle, indicating that the friction forces are not dominated by coulomb friction alone. The possible causes for this will be discussed later in the article.

sec.title: Inter-string friction
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows values of vr, θr and ωr and derived values of Ix, Iy and μt for all string types against the inter-string friction measure τ (in seconds). Linear regression equations such as those in Figure 3 were used to calculate values of these dependent variables for each string condition at inbound backspins of 0 and 300 rad·s−1 with error bars indicated by the standard error of the estimate (SEE). Table 2 shows the results of the multiple linear regressions calculated using all impact data with τ, k, vi, θi and ωi as independent variables. Figure 5.
Impacts of pressurized tennis balls with changing friction at 0 and 300 rad·s−1: (a) rebound speed vr (b) rebound angle θr (c) rebound spin ωr (d) vertical impulse Iy (e) horizontal impulse Ix and (f) traction μt. (Notation: N and P indicates nylon and polyester respectively with L (low) or H (high) friction).

The graphs in Figure 5 are relatively complex but one of the main features is that impacts at 40° are different to those at 60°. For instance, at 60° vr increases as τ increases (i.e. μs decreases) while at 40° vr appears to reach a maximum at medium values of τ. A clear difference is seen in Figure 5(c) which shows that rebound topspin increases as τ increases at 40° but reaches a maximum at medium values of τ for impacts at 60°. Iy in Figure 5(d) is relatively independent of τ and μs (and is confirmed by a lack of dependence on τ in Table 2). Ix in Figure 5(e) on the other hand, appears to have a different relationship with τ and μs; at 60° Ix decreases with τ while at 40° it has a minimum at medium values of τ. The data again suggests a different mechanism horizontally to that vertically, which increases in dominance as μs decreases. The following section will suggest a hypothesis that explains the effect of μs on impacts at all θi and ωi.

sec.title: Overview of mechanics
sec.p: The results shown in Figures 3 to 5 indicate that a change in μs can have a large effect on the rebound of the ball. The specific effect is dependent on the initial conditions of the impact. It appears that the normal forces throughout impact do not vary much for different μs and ωi since the vertical impulse Iy tends to remain relatively constant. In order to obtain a better understanding of string movements, a mirror was positioned under the racket and additional impacts were filmed in a similar manner to Cross and Lindsey.19 Inspection of the high speed videos suggest that Ix may be controlled by the tangential movement of the longitudinal strings over the cross-strings during impact. Ix, by definition, is determined by the magnitude of the forces F(t), and its duration during impact. For a ball that slides throughout impact, the effect of a high Ix is generally to decrease vr (since Iy is a constant) and increase the moment around the ball’s centre of mass causing ωr to increase. The following hypothesis proposes how the horizontal displacement of the longitudinal strings over the cross-strings during impact affect both F(t) and its duration, and subsequently Ix.

Small but unavoidable variations in the impact location on the string bed made it difficult to determine the exact mechanics from the videos but the following discussion highlights the main observations. At high μs, the strings did not move tangentially very much, while at low μs one or more strings were seen to move laterally in the direction of the ball and in some cases spring back, either during or just after impact. The frictional force F(t) depends upon the relative motion between the surface of the ball and the strings: at steep impact angles, the ball slides for some of the impact although the sliding distance is short and limited to 1 or 2 strings; at shallow impact angles, the sliding distance is longer with 2 or more strings involved. A ball with backspin slides further than one without because the ball is further from the point of rolling. F(t) may reduce to zero if the ball begins to roll during impact (Sr = 1) or even reverse direction if the ball overspins.

If the longitudinal strings move tangentially during impact then a number of things might occur:
The string will move with the ball so that the relative motion between the contact area of the ball and the strings is low and F(t) reduces (Figure 6(a)). A lower force means the change in tangential velocity and spin is less pronounced and the ball is less likely to reach the point of rolling.
The displaced strings may return to their original position beneath the ball.
If the ball is sliding or instantaneously rolling the relative tangential velocity between the ball and strings will increase, leading to an increase in F(t). The increase in F(t) will reduce the ball’s tangential velocity whilst increasing the topspin (Figure 6(b)).
If the ball is over-spinning F(t) will reduce, causing a less pronounced reduction in topspin and a less pronounced increase in tangential velocity (Figure 6 (c)).
The displaced strings return to their original position as the pressure at the rear of the ball drops to zero as the ball leaves the string bed. There is subsequently no applied force F to the ball.
Figure 6.
Effect of string movements on tangential ball velocity and topspin.

This thought process is used in the following to explain the variation in ball rebound in Figure 5. Sr was calculated using equation (4) and used to approximate values for low, medium and high friction strings (Table 3). These were calculated using best fit lines through the raw data of Sr vs spin, allowing errors to be estimated using the standard error of the estimate (SEE). Table 3.
Estimated spin ratio Sr for θi = 40 and 60° and ωi = 0 and 300 rad·s−1 for impacts on strings with high, medium and low μs.
Sr (±SEE)
40° 60°
τ(s) μs 0 rad·s−1 300 rad·s−1 0 rad·s−1 300 rad·s−1
Nylon high (NH) 4.6 High 0.99 ± 0.14 1.00 ± 0.14 1.03 ± 0.12 0.82 ± 0.12
Nylon (N) 10.7 Medium 0.94 ± 0.15 1.19 ± 0.15 1.25 ± 0.12 1.19 ± 0.12
Polyester low (PL) 17.9 Low 1.14 ± 0.11 1.57 ± 0.11 0.77 ± 0.06 0.25 ± 0.06

sec.title: High μs: e.g. NH (τ = 4.6 s)
sec.p: The mechanics of the impact are simplest when the inter-string friction is high. At high μs the longitudinal strings do not move, so the string bed acts in a similar fashion to a rigid surface, and the ball tends to roll at the end of impact. As the strings don't move, then the spin ratio parameter is most valid. At steep impacts with no spin (i.e. θi = 40° and ωi = 0 rad·s−1) the ball initially slides across the string-bed but rolls quite early so that F(t) drops close to zero. The ball tends to roll at the end of impact, as indicated by a spin ratio close to one in Table 3. At θi = 40° and ωi = 300 rad·s−1, the ball slides across the string bed for a longer duration than at 0 rad·s−1 causing Ix to increase from 0.47 to 0.75 Ns (Figure 5(e)). Although Ix is higher, the ball still tends to roll at the end of impact despite the spin being lower than at 0 rad·s−1 (Figure 5(c)). At shallower impacts (θi = 60° and ωi = 0 rad·s−1) the ball slides for a longer proportion of the impact than at 40° causing Ix to increase from 0.47 to 0.65 Ns (Figure 5(e)). This causes the ball to rebound slower and with more spin than at 40°. At θi = 60° and ωi = 300 rad·s−1 the ball slides throughout the impact (Sr = 0.82 in Table 3) so that F(t) is proportional to R(t) throughout and Ix rises further to 0.77 Ns.

sec.title: Medium μs: e.g. N (τ = 10.7 s)
sec.p: High friction strings are not necessarily the norm in tennis and as string friction reduces to a more 'standard' value the mechanics of the impact become more complex. As μs is lowered to medium values of friction, the longitudinal strings are more likely to displace a small amount across the cross-strings during impact. At 40°, the relative motion of the strings with the ball reduces F(t) for a short period, reducing Ix in comparison to high μs values. Since Iy is relatively constant, the ball rebounds slightly faster and ωr increases as the ball tends to either (1) roll at the end of impact when the inbound spin is 0 rad/s (SR = 0.94, Table 3) or (2) over-spin at the end of the impact when the inbound backspin is 300 rad/s (Sr = 1.19, Table 3). At 60°, however, the balls may be overspinning at the end of impact resulting in high topspin (SR > 1, Table 3).

sec.title: Low μs: e.g. PL (τ = 17.9 s)
sec.p: At low inter-string friction, the mechanics of the impact are the most complex as the strings tend to displace more. At the lowest μs, the longitudinal strings are likely to displace a large amount earlier during impact and return while the ball is still in contact with the stringbed. At 40° this causes Ix to increase compared to medium μs. At the start of the impact the movement of the strings reduces the relative velocity between the ball and string bed. Towards the end of the impact the strings move back towards their original positions since there is in increase in string tension (due to their lateral deformation) and the inter-string friction is low. The strings apply a moment to the contact zone of the ball causing it to overspin (SR > 1, Table 3). The effect is more pronounced when the inbound ball has backspin due to the greater lateral deformation of the strings. At 60°, on the other hand, the ball slides a long distance, moving from one string to the next causing each to displace in turn and the strings to return as the pressure at the rear of the ball is released. The ball slips from one string to the next and is likely to slip at the end of impact (SR < 1, Table 3).

The analysis is confounded to some extent by the effect of string stiffness since the amount of horizontal movement is likely to be limited by the rise in tension in the strings. Table 2 shows that stiffness has a weak effect and tends to increase vr, while decreasing ωr. Since this relationship is derived for all θi and ωi it is difficult to say what the true effect would be. However, it can be postulated that a stiffer string would move less far so that steep impacts might tend to roll while shallow impacts might tend to slide.

Some researchers use the dynamic coefficient of friction μt as a measure of the coefficient of friction between the balls and strings. Figure 5(f) shows that at steep impact angles μt is relatively constant and increases with inbound backspin. In comparison, μt decreases as μs decreases for shallower impacts because of the increased movement of the strings over each other rather than the decrease in friction between the ball and strings. Equation (3) should be used carefully to determine the coefficient of friction since it represents traction rather than the more traditional sense of Coulomb friction, as stated by Allen et al.10

The effect of changing the coefficient of friction of the tennis strings is more complex than initially envisaged. The instinct is that a reduction in μs might reduce the friction of the ball travelling over the surface. However, a larger effect is seen in the movement of the strings over each other during impact. Some of the consequences of a change of μs have been described here, but the analysis could be enhanced through measurements of string movements. A potential method would be to use a rig where a camera could be placed behind the racket with the focal axis perpendicular to the string bed. In addition, an appropriate method should be developed for measuring the static and dynamic coefficient of friction of tennis strings. These methods should enable validation of a finite element model, which would in turn enable temporal impact data to be obtained. Ultimately the results need to be applied to determine the effect of inter-string friction on a typical tennis strike.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Impacts of tennis balls on a tennis racket show that the dominant factors for a fixed impact speed are the impact angle and backspin. The inter-string friction μs has different consequences depending upon whether the strings slide across each other during contact, which in turn depends on the initial values of angle and spin. At high μs, the strings tend not to move and the ball tends to roll off the strings except at shallow angles when the backspin is high enough to induce sliding throughout impact. At medium μs, the strings slide a small amount horizontally reducing the horizontal impulse at steep impacts. At shallow impacts string movements may cause the ball to overspin as it rebounds. At low μs, the strings slide a lot horizontally; at steep impacts the balls tend to overspin while at shallow impacts the ball slides from one string to the next and slides at the end of impact. It was concluded, therefore, that the dominant effect of a change in inter-string friction was in the string movement rather than the coefficient of friction between the ball and strings and that the effect was dependent upon impact angle and spin.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Many thanks to Daniel Ura for the numerous recording of impacts using high-speed video.
